had some introduction to ml Commons in our last episode which will'll Link in our show notes but for those maybe that
haven't heard that or maybe want a sort of refresher could you just give us a
little bit of an idea about what ml Commons is why it exists and and what are some of the things that you're doing
yeah absolutely so the mission of ml Commons is really making machine learning better for everyone so I think
of our goal as being you know sort of how do we stimulate innovation in ml in a way that you know really benefits
society and the whole world so we were started you know it was a very informal
collaboration starting in 2018 but we actually uh formed a a
nonprofit in 2020 that I am you know the founder and executive director of we've got an
amazing team and it's an industry Consortium so we're bringing together a lot of heavyweights in the ml World from
the system side from the software side from the cloud side you know who are all focused on this and and we you know that
mission of making ml better for the whole world we have sort of three real pillars to that and and one is
benchmarks in metric and so the first thing that a lot of people know us for is uh ml perf which
are the industry standard benchmarks for the speed of training neural networks
and doing inference and uh you know actually one of the things that's been really cool since we've talked is you know I think when we first talked we
might have only had two of the benchmarks in our suet up and running and we're now uh what I like to say is covering from microwatts to megawatts so
these smallest systems we've measured performance on are like you know maybe tens of microwatt you know really deeply
embedded iot devices up to the world's number one supercomputer which is 20
megawatt and sort of everything in between and so you know you can see what's really cool and I have some
slides that I use in Keynotes saying like hey if you look at the two and a half years we've been around you would
expect that just through Mo's law alone ml solutions would be about 2 and a half X faster and that's great right you know
we want to make your life easier Daniel when you're doing the work but uh if you look at the ml perf data that we have
actually it's more like 16 to 30X faster and so it's really cool to see you know when you get benchmarks and when you get
metrics and everyone starts really rowing in the right direction the kind of momentum you can get in the industry
so that's one example of ways we can make ml better for everyone is just you know being able to train bigger models
and do it faster and really bring those capabilities out sort of the second pillar is the one that brings me here is
uh our data sets and you know I like to think of data sets as really being the raw ingredient for ML if uh the
Industrial Revolution was powered by iron and coal not the most
environmentally stuff you know we're really powered by data right and it's you know I think at s right you guys
understand that just as well as everyone else you know if you want to start talking in new languages or working with
new texts you can't get from English to uru without some new data right and
bringing large scale open nicely curated data is a huge Boon for the industry
because even at some of the biggest shops in the world you know places like Google or Amazon their researchers want
to use public data because the whole point is that you're sharing techniques
that everyone can use in driving the industry forward yeah that's really interesting sometimes I get the question
when I'm working on various data sets like what the benefit and like you said we we deal with this at s to like we
have a bunch of data in our archive or wherever that linguists have gathered like over very long time and sometimes
the question comes up well like first off why would anyone in the industry be
interested in sort of like this strange data and we can answer that but then secondly like why would we want to make
this open like how would that benefit like our organization to work on open
data sets versus like closed and proprietary stuff when you're having
those conversations how do you express that to people like the maybe the business sort of case for contributing
to open data sets because you do engage with large organizations on the data sets you work with so how is that
phrased to their sort of leadership yeah so I think it it depends on the companies right so there's some
companies where their data really is a critical differentiator and they probably don't ever want to open it but
even in the case where that is true so like I'll give you an example so there's a company a crio in Europe that actually
uh was really fantastically cooperative and opened up one of their data sets for
our use it was an older data set that they weren't super concerned about a
competitor having access to right and they said like look if you use this data set for your benchmarks systems are
going to get faster for what we want to do so this is a way that you can kind of
in some ways punch above your weight in getting the attention of the industry right and I'm sure you've talked to
folks about how you know when you start training on a data set the models begin to specialize a bit for that and so you
know if you want your use case to be popular making it open is a really good
one and then a lot of Our member companies you know if you look at someone like Intel or Nvidia more open
data means more ml means more people doing cool things with computers means more sales so you know in a lot of cases
I think you hit the nail on the head which is as a nonprofit and Industry Consortium I can't force people to do
what they don't want to do I can provide persuasion and I can try to help them
understand where our interests are aligned and I think there are a lot of ways where that's great or you know Chris you work in in the defense and
intelligence community so I had a really cool meeting late last year with some
folks there and one of the things they were saying that they love about open data is certain parts of that Community
have real difficulties spending money through normal channels indeed and one of the interesting things specifically
about speech is by and large the intelligence Community tends to care about languages that are not very
commercially viable for like regular products right sure there's not as much
interest let's rewind it 10 years ago if you asked like you know the CIA or
whoever like what language would you love to have like an automagical translator they'd be like oh Arabic for sure right and they wouldn't have said
English or Mandarin right which are you know probably the two most popular speech data set flavors out there right
and so yeah I think just open data is hugely powerful in enabling researchers
and everyone to sort of work together on these problems do you think there's a cultural aspect to it in terms of people
getting used to this idea cuz when you position it like that you can clearly see the business case for it I know in
my experience it seems like some years back we went through this with open source software and people struggled to
see that business case and understand and now it is swept almost all aspects of business do you envision that use
case benefit in terms of being able to influence how things go and participate
that in the larger scale that that is going to be more widely adopted over the years Ahad yeah I think so and I mean I
think one of the other things that I'd say is you know when you look at open data in a lot of cases even where you
might be differentiating via your own data like in a lot of cases it's going to be additive right so let's say you
want to do a medical transcription thing you might not want to donate to the wide
world like all of your work on translating and decoding specialized
medical terms like tacki cardia right but if you were going to do train like a
natural language model you know some version of say Bert right you might start with Bert on a large public data
set like Wikipedia or a crawl of the web and then you'd say well you know I'm going to add on my special sauce later
to fine-tune or supplement or augment that and so one of the ways I think about this is that getting from zero to
product is a really big push and you need the data to get there but it's not the only thing you need right there's
also the whole process of how do I productize it how do I test it how do I make sure it's not going to do you know
wild and crazy things that I don't expect and if I as an organization can
provide some open data and get the whole world a few steps down that path and sort of accelerate things that's just
good for everyone I'm curious I got to followup for you on that and that is I know that there are people listening to
this because it's in my head as well that are thinking my organization needs to do better on that and as we talk
about the decision point of about how do I make the business case and and what
should go open what should we keep as our secret sauce and all that any guidelines on how to make such an
evaluation I realize that use cases vary a lot but I have had conversation with
with people where they either want to just throw everything open or they want to do everything as their special sauce
but there doesn't seem to be a a method to the madness on what what constitutes the two how would an
organization do that recognize that by going open they selfishly they get the benefit of being able to steer things
but they still get to keep their secret sauce any thoughts about how to make such an evaluation yeah so the other
thing I was actually going to mention is you know one of the things that our organization is very dedicated to is the
maintenance and upkeep of these and you know so if you think it of imag net right that really started this round of
innovation in machine learning right and it was imag net and then the realization that hey Alex net plus gpus plus imag
net beats humans at image recognition oh my gosh right and and now imag net is
fantastic it's amazing but you know now it's old it hasn't been updated there's
some legal issues associated with the licensing and you know so imagine we're doing speech the text and we did that in
2019 that model that data set would not have anything about covid or Corona virus or any of these other things so
you know you want to keep these things up to date and that that does cost some amount of money and so by offloading
that to the Community or you know ml Commons we're curating our stuff it's part of where our budget goes that can
be very helpful in terms of combining Community Resources and so that's another aspect of the business case but
to answer your question I think it is very easy to slide into these binaries right it's just it's a very natural way
of thinking and where we've had a lot of success I think is usually where there
is some sort of research folks involved or you know some sort of specialist who
can think about this and reason about it these kind of Endeavors inevitably
involve your legal department that's a great point and we don't want to get folks in trouble and so there's all
sorts of issues about how is it collected do you have the right permissions gdpr and a lawyer is probably not going
to be able to give you the insights as to what is commercially valuable what is
commercially threatening could it be monetized in other ways or no is this just the thing that makes sense so you
kind of do need some element of the business and and potentially technical community and so we found that that is
oftentimes a very helpful driver one of the things that is beautiful about the machine Learning Community is I think
there's a openness is in our DNA and so I think for a lot of researchers that is
sort of a default mode of thinking and that is

so David as ml comments was thinking about this sort of pillar of data sets
and obviously there's a lot of different data sets that could be valuable to the
ml community and all sorts of data whether that be one type of data or multimodal data or like all all sorts of
things how did ml comment sort of settle on an initial maybe focus on speech data
cuz I know we'll be kind of transitioning to talk about a couple of the very impressive data sets that were
recently released but they're both speech data sets or speech related data sets so how did that come about yeah so
when I think about the data set problems that I want my organization to or the
organization I serve to tackle I sort of think about it as two sides of the equation return and investment and by by
return I really mean what's the impact right and so I want to be working on problems that'll have an impact where
we're going to provide some very clearly differentiated very valuable things that the community doesn't have if all you do
is produce something that already exists with a slightly friendlier license that can have a big impact but you know it's
not as great as you know I'm now one of our data sets right is the first in many
many languages right that's like a qualitative change in the landscape that's like really exciting and then the
other side of that is do we have the right people to do it and what is the investment that's involved there and can
we bring that skill set together and are we uniquely positioned to do that and for us speech was very much ground zero
for a couple reasons so one is we actually want to build up the infrastructure around building these
data sets because part of our the theory behind our organization is that actually a lot of the plumbing behind the scenes
there's some commonality to it and sharing that can be helpful me obviously there's greater alignment between two
speech data sets than you know speech and vision but still there's a lot of just general wrangling you got to do and
also some of the leads on our project had prior experience building speech
data sets and there was a very real desire to have and all of our data sets
are permissively licensed for both research and commercial use and there's a real desire to build something big
enough to train an endtoend speeech model on and then begin to tackle diversity and so those things all kind
of lined up for us in that there was sort of a gap in what was out there and we had the right expertise and we
thought that the impact would be big yeah so maybe you could just describe generally there there's two large data
sets that that you've released recently you know we'll link of course to the specific uh information about those and
people can obtain them and download them and and start working with them but maybe just give us a picture of each of
those and what the goal was with with each one yeah yeah so the first one is
called The People's speech and I think I talked with with you guys about this last year and that is uh 30,000 hours of
labeled speech data and it's sort of intended for speech recognition purposes
but you can use it for a lot of other things we've had people who downloaded it to do like Den noising filters for
acoustical applications and it's like I said permissively licensed conversational speech so it's not just
read audio books as was sort of common before and it's very big it's 30,000
hours is about I think two to three terabytes and part of the point here is
we've got you know when I think about speech I sort of think about three dimensions to the data sets one is size
one is the languages and then the other is sort of the context and like do you have noisy speech or is it you know
something really clearly recorded are there kids playing in the background and other things like that and so this is
putting the Stak in the ground on the size and you know we can work on the other things and like I said it's big
enough to train an end to-end model so kind of over the 10 to 15,000 hour
Tipping Point so that is sort of going deep and big in the size dimension and
then the second one which is nicely complimentary is the multilingual spoken
words Corpus and this is exciting because this is really pushing the boundaries on the diversity angle from
the number of languages and so that it's um not for speech recognition but for keyword spotting right so recognizing
keywords um a modest number of keywords and it is 23 million clips that are each
about one second long covering 340,000 keywords with 115,000 different Source
speakers in 50 languages and the thing to me that's really cool about that is those languages cover 5 billion human
speakers right so this is the majority of the world's population and most of these languages this is the first
existing data set for keyword spotting in those languages and certainly the first under such a nice permissive
license and you know we're talking about languages that are not supported by these home assistants right if you you
know I don't want to pick on any one company but if you look at a lot of the home assistants or things like that they might support a dozen languages but
there's a lot of languages where there's not a lot of support and so you know bringing that capability to these new
communities is really exciting like I it was very cool to see some of the people tweeting about hey my language is in
here or getting emails about how can I add my language so that's pushing forward in a different dimension but
again also speech so I'm I'm kind of curious you know I've worked with data sets from whatever you know the task
that I'm focused on but I've never done anything at the scale of having to put
the data together what's involved in that you know if you're looking at you have the keyword spotting and you have
the speech recognition use cases and you have massive amounts of content that
you're doing I would imagine that there is a level of organization and and effort required Way Beyond what most of
us that are just doing typical day-to-day machine learning models are having to deal with how do you even
start that how do you approach such a engagement H that's a really good question so our team is pretty small in
terms of the number of Engineers so I'm not sure that you know resource-wise it's not like you know we're coming in
with 10 people or whatever fulltime or anything like that you know I would say I think the thing that we really wanted
to focus on was because we knew as you said this is like a big problem I think we had to focus on things that scaled
initially and you know really good example of that is we did a backof the envelope calculation of like okay what
would it take to label the data manually and you know I think we calculated it
would be on the order of about 10 million do that's a bit of a budget
right there right yes that's uh several years of budget for my nonprofit and we've got to keep the lights on we got
to pay the employees you know so that was out of the question and so we actually I think one of the things we
really wanted to focus on was building the tools and leaning into compute rather than manual labor and so
you know we were able to label the data and generate the labels using uh
computer systems for under about $20,000 so I think it's sort of attention to
that and building up the tools and all of the tools are open source by the way you know not only can you go and get the
data set but you can get the tools we use to create it and you know we'd love to see people updating them fixing bugs
whatever it is and see Community adoption of all of those pieces but you
know it's also again yeah I think it does come down to the right tools right if you're building one house you want
one set of tools if you are building a 50-story apartment building or a dozen houses you're going to you know have
slightly different infrastructure yeah I would be kind of curious to maybe dig a little bit into that because when you're
creating a labeled data set people might think oh I I want gold standard data
right which necessarily in their mind means human labeled right without a sort
of machine in the loop of creating the gold standard data so maybe describe a little bit more like why this sort of
machine process can create something that's useful to train a machine on I
guess would be the question right or put another way okay so the snake is eating its own tail does that actually work
right right or or we left and we're like there's no snake anymore so first of all I think the technical team had some
great instincts here and you know one of the big hypotheses is as you say like a
lot of people will focus on extremely high quality data but it's also pretty common that if you have some bad data in
there it may not really be a huge problem and so I think part of this is
accepting that a large amount of modus quality dat and actually we did we can
talk about some of the details because we did in generating the labels we actually did figure out or or try to
estimate how many of them were good and like a big chunk of it was done you know sort of perfectly some of it was done to
sort of human quality some of it was worse and you know I think there was a
bit of a gamble there that that would ultimately prove to be useful but we do
know that machine learning is very good at handling kind of rough inputs and so
it seemed like a pretty good hypothesis there you know it's also the the ways
that a machine in the loop for labeling go wrong are going to be probably a lot different than a human I'm I'm just kind
of curious I'm sure Daniel already knows this but as you as you're putting these data sets together is it kind of one
shot and you're done and it's there or is there a management of that data set over time do you go back and and relabel
with new tools or anything or is that or do you kind of move on to a whole new data set how do you think about producing things I guarant to you like
uh any engineer we tried a few things and the first things did not work I'll give you an example I'm I know
we evaluated several different forced aligners so we started for people speech
by uh scraping data where there was a transcript and the audio but they
weren't necessarily temporally aligned which you need to train a speech to text
model so we did our own transcription using uh CDI with an
engram language model and so we came up with our estimated transcription and
then we reinforced alignment on that to get the time stamps right and all of this audio came with subtitles but just
as an example sometimes the subtitles are a little wonky right like you might get a subtitle maybe the language spoken
is French and the subtitle is in English or maybe it's a description of a picture or something like that so you can get all sorts of really interesting problems
and so we tried different aligners and we did find one that we thought you know
solved some of these problems didn't solve all of them but we definitely tried out a bunch of different things
and to us one of the proof in the pudding sort of things was actually training a speech detex model on our
data set and seeing how comparable it was to using something like libis speech which is much smaller but is is sort of
the gold standard today and you know we got in the ballpark of Liber speech which we're like that's good enough but
I will tell you we did not start out in the ballpark of Liber speech there's you know all sorts of problems you know you
have like mismatch transcripts where things are just you know but you find the problems and you Hammer them down
one by one that's my experience I don't know Daniel what about you yeah I mean this is a sort of never never ending
process right and I think like you were talking about imag net and others you know this is only like things get sale
and need to updated and language especially is like always changing very
rapidly and like like you say if something was released like before covid and you need like covid Health words and
stuff after Co it needs to be updated as part of your release do you have a
mechanism for people to like make sort of contributions or feedback or sort of
uh human evaluation type of feedback or or anything like that yeah so you know again we're big on
community we have a an open Discord channel that you can drop in and and tell us what's great tell us what
doesn't work when we released it as you might expect the initial sets of comments were this is really amazing but
we you know we found this hitch so we're we're nailing those down and we've got you know a Google group and mailing list
for this and so and again all the code is open source so you know folks want to file bugs and I mean the thing to me
that is most exciting is now that it's released like a year from now what are people doing with it like to me that's
really the sort of thing that's very cool one of the other things I would actually mention just briefly you said
an example of a scale thing that we had to work on is when we were initially doing the forced alignment one of the
things we found is that you know just using outof the Box software was not sufficiently fast and so we actually had
to go through and optimize our forced aligner both the acoustic model and the
language model and get them running on an accelerator on a on a GPU and at that
point we were able to get 250X real time and so that's an example of paying
attention to scaling and sort of systems where it's like yeah 30,000 hours is a lot you don't want to be renting an
Amazon instance for 30,000 hours because a we got to release it but okay you cut
that down by a factor of 250 and it's like okay we can rent a few of those right so there's all sorts of things

actually some reasonably obscure languages like Basque catalon Persian and then of course some standard ones

first of all it's a lot of languages and also some of the work in this paper was about okay when we say low resource does
that mean you can't use it or you know what does that really mean and actually what we found is you can use a lot of
the low resource languages I think for like few shot training and fine-tuning
examples right and so that is really powerful in terms of bringing out new
capabilities and uh you know I think the blog post I wrote was sort of cheeky like giving a voice to five billion
people right I think especially with speech you know text is a slightly different scenario but especially with

top 100 and then you drop off sort of very quickly in terms of resources that
are out there all the way out to 7,000 something languages so you actually
don't have to go very far as soon as you get past like the first 10 or so top
languages of the world with speech data it drops off like very rapidly and so
yeah it's really cool to see this effort that pushes that out there and that's really encouraging and my brain's
already going with ideas of of how to use this I think it's also interesting you know looking at it how you've I mean
it's one thing to release data but also it's very useful at least in my view to
provide additional metadata and annotations along with those words like I see you have parts of speech and
semantic categorization which is all really interesting and and something that I think will be one of those things
that drives maybe surprising uses of the data set so yeah I'm not sure when that

the curation process and how can you improve things over time and make it more useful and and part of it is you
know we talked to the member organizations along the way as we were doing this to get some feedback on what
would be useful and the other thing I should mention is actually the multilingual spoken words Corpus is actually a data set generator
so you can sort of dial in your own keywords right and I think because of that capability it's useful to know like
what parts of speech are there and what are sort of the content types in the the topics and domains so to me it's part of
making it low friction in usable and also just understanding really what's
going on and I think that kind of anal is is super important for large scale uh
data sets like to jump around a little bit uh and talk about the people's speech one of the things we did is we
sort of randomly sampled about 5,000 hours to find out what kind of background noise we had because you know
if you're going to train a model you want to know and you know we found lots of music in the background conversation
basketball bounces all sorts of things and ultimately as a data scientist just
getting this is really good and I should mention for the multilingual words Corpus it's built on top of common voice
so what we have is this really cool pipeline that can pull in a data set and
what's cool about common voice is it's ordinary people so anything that goes into common voice will eventually get
Incorporated in into ours and there's going to be good background noise and
different kind of recording circumstances but I think it really helps to the extent that we can to try
to characterize that kind of in the spirit of if you build it they will come well kind of member organizations are
you kind of pulling in now that you have this these new data sets out there and as you're attracting new participants
how are you organizing them and how are you able to put them all together in such a way that it kind of continues to
development forward in a cohesive way how do you manage that process oh that's a good one well so we released these
data sets uh in the middle of December so it it hasn't been that much time so I
